raw_text:
Scotland v Italy (Sat)
 
 Murrayfield, Edinburgh
 
 Saturday, 26 February
 
 1400 GMT
 
 BBC1, Five Live and this website
 
 Victory for the Azzurri in Rome last year saw Scotland end their campaign without a victory. And the pressure is on Scotland coach Matt Williams as he seeks a first Six Nations victory at the eighth attempt. Italy have lost both their opening games at home to Ireland and Wales, but travel to Edinburgh with high hopes.
 
 Their coach John Kirwan has warned his side they must eradicate the errors that blighted their loss to Wales however or risk suffering a third successive defeat. "If the defeat against Wales has taught us anything, it's that at this level we can't make any mistakes," Kirwan said. "In the Six Nations, every error you make will come at a high price. "We have to be aggressive for 80 minutes, keep calm in every situation and display great maturity on the pitch.
 
 "It will be fundamental to keep cool in the difficult moments - in the key situations of the game." Kirwan has recalled the experienced Cristian Stoica at centre and drafted in David dal Maso at open-side after star flanker Mauro Bergamasco was ruled out for the rest of the tournament. Scotland have also made two changes, Simon Webster replacing Simon Danielli on the wing and Simon Taylor returning for his first Test in a year, for injured flanker Jason White. Taylor's recovery from a serious knee injury is a major boost to Scottish hopes. "He is one of the world-class players in the tournament and you want them in your team," acknowledged Williams.
 
 Despite a record of only two victories from 14 Tests, Williams insists he is revelling in the pressure. "I actually really enjoy seeing how you cope with such pressure as a coach," he said, optimistic despite opening defeats to France and Ireland. "We were confident for those two first games and we are confident we can beat Italy too," he added.
 
 : C Paterson; S Webster, A Craig, H Southwell, S Lamont; D Parks, C Cusiter; T Smith, G Bulloch (capt), G Kerr; S Grimes, S Murray; S Taylor, J Petrie, A Hogg.
 
 R Russell, B Douglas, N Hines, J Dunbar, M Blair, G Ross, B Hinshelwood.
 
 R de Marigny; Mirco Bergamasco, C Stoica, A Masi, L Nitoglia; L Orquera, A Troncon; A Lo Cicero, F Ongaro, M Castrogiovanni; S Dellape, M Bortolami (capt); A Persico, D Dal Maso, S Parisse.
 
 G Intoppa, S Perugini, CA del Fava, S Orlando, P Griffen, R Pedrazzi, KP Robertson.
llama3.2:1b: Scotland will travel to Italy seeking their first Six Nations victory at the eighth attempt.
Coach Matt Williams is under pressure after last year's defeat in Rome.
Italy coach John Kirwan has warned his team they must avoid mistakes if they want a win.
He also recalled Cristian Stoica and made changes, including replacing Mauro Bergamasco with David dal Maso.
Scotland coach Matt Williams is confident despite the pressure, saying he enjoys it as a coach and wants to beat Italy.
llama3.2:3b: Scotland's coach Matt Williams seeks a first Six Nations victory at the eighth attempt as they face Italy at Murrayfield.
Italy coach John Kirwan warns his team to eradicate errors made in their loss to Wales, while Scotland have made changes with new player Simon Taylor returning after a year-long injury.
gemma2:2b: Scotland will face Italy in their Six Nations match on February 26th at Murrayfield.
Scotland needs a victory to avoid another Six Nations winless campaign.
Italy has struggled in their opening matches against Ireland and Wales but is hoping for a turnaround in Edinburgh.
Scotland coach Matt Williams faces pressure with the team needing to break their recent losing streak.
Both teams have made several changes, including Italy's call back of veteran center Cristian Stoica and Scotland's return of Simon Taylor.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Scotland defeated Italy in the Six Nations rugby tournament on Saturday night, and Scotland coach Matt Williams is confident his team will have a chance of winning the game.
The Scots have only lost two out of their 14 games played this season at the Six Nations, but there are still some big games to come against France and Ireland.

Williams insists they have a strong team in their ranks, with experienced players like Cristian Stoica on the wing, David Dal Maso in open-side play, Jason White injured for the tournament, Simon Webster returning from injury, Simon Taylor being his first Test since a year ago, and Simon Danielli taking the side to the semi-finals.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Scotland vs Italy: 2017 Six Nations match preview.
Williams aims for first win in eight tries.
Italy coach warns of crucial errors needed to avoid third consecutive defeat, targeting experienced Cristian Stoica and David dal Maso replacements.
Scotland's changes include Simon Webster at wing and Simon Taylor returning after injury; Williams relishes pressure while opening loss to France and Ireland prompts confidence.
Scottie, Smith, Grimes, Murray lineups detailed.
qwen2.5:3b: Scotland face Italy at Murrayfield in Edinburgh on Saturday, February 26th at 14:00 GMT.
BBC1, Five Live and this website will broadcast the match.
Scotland last won a Six Nations game eight attempts ago.
Coach Matt Williams seeks his first victory despite opening losses to France and Ireland.
Italian coach John Kirwan is urging caution after their narrow loss to Wales.
Italy recall experience at center Cristian Stoica and draft in David dal Maso.
Scottish team includes Simon Webster, Simon Taylor, and Jason White's replacement, S. Taylor.
Despite poor record, Williams remains confident.
Italy lineup features R. de Marigny, Mirco Bergamasco, A. Troncon among others.
opencoder:1.5b:
The text provided summarizes the following:
1.
The winner of the Six Nations Winter Games against Italy in 2022 (Italy) was Scotland.
They scored a victory against the Azzurri last year but ended their campaign without a full victory.
They made a first Six Nations match at the eighth attempt, and the pressure is on them as they seek a first match at home.
Despite the absence of victories, they are facing the pressure to continue playing in the same format.
With limited victories from 14 Tests, Williams insists he is revelling in the pressure.
However, they have made progress and are confident that they can beat Italy at this level.

The key players were C Paterson (Scotland), S Webster (Scotland), A Craig (England), H Southwell (Wales), S Lamont (Scotland), D Parks (England), C Cusiter (Ireland), T Smith (Ireland), G Bulloch (Wales), S Grimes (Scotland), S Taylor (Scotland), J Petrie (Canada), A Hogg (Wales).
They went for two tests against France and Ireland, with Simon White recovering from a serious knee injury.

Lastly, the team's coaches were C Paterson, S Webster, A Craig, H Southwell, S Lamont, D Parks, C Cusiter, T Smith, G Bulloch (capt), G Kerr, S Grimes, S Taylor, J Petrie, A Hogg, Mirco Bergamasco, C Stoica, A Masi, L Nitoglia, L Orquera, A Troncon, A Lo Cicero, F Ongaro, M Castrogiovanni, S Dellape (capt), A Persico, D Dal Maso, S Parisse.
They went for a match at the eighth attempt against Italy and they scored it in 3-2, marking a success.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The match was between Scotland (away) and Italy at 14:00 GMT on Saturday, February 26, 2024, for the eighth Six Nations title attempt.

Key details include Scotland's pressure from losing to Wales last year, their coach Kirwan emphasizing calm under pressure, the start of their home campaign with a record-two wins, and player news like Taylor's recovery and starting lineup substitutions.
Italy is traveling to Edinburgh after two losses.
The match highlights various players arriving with new starters.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Scottish national team is facing pressure ahead of their Six Nations championship match against Italy, which will take place on Satuday, February 26th at 1400 GMT in Edinburgh.
The pressure is on the coach Matt Williams as he seeks to secure his first victory in his eight attempts at leading Scotland's rugby team.
The Azzzurri have lost both their opening games in Rome against Ireland and Wales by defeats, but will travel to Edinburgh with high hopes due to their recent campaign being without a win.
Coach John Kirwan has warned of the importance of staying calm and aggressive on the pitch, keeping cool for key situations that may come up during the game.
Scotland has made several changes, including bringing back winger Simon Webster from injury and recalling wing David Dal Maso, as well as welcoming centre Simon Taylor back after his injury.
The Scottish team is confident of beating Italy despite being in a similar situation to their opening matches.
Coach Matt Williams has expressed his excitement for the pressure, stating that he relishes it and sees it as a major boost to the team's chances.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Scotland secured a crucial victory over Italy in the Six Nations at Murrayfield, Edinburgh on Saturday, defeating their opponents by a score of 26-14.
The game saw Scotland's coach Matt Williams face his toughest challenge yet as they tried to end their losing streak and break Italy's winning run.
Italy lost both their opening matches at home against Ireland and Wales, but traveled to Edinburgh with high expectations.
Despite the pressure of the tournament so far, Scotland secured a morale-boosting victory against Italy, marking the first win in 14 Six Nations appearances for the Scottish team.
The match itself was full of intense moments and crucial errors that could have cost Scotland dearly.
In their opening game against Wales, Scotland made multiple mistakes that cost them a win, while in their second match, they were defeated by Ireland.
Despite these losses, they persevered and displayed great maturity throughout the rest of the tournament.
The key to success for Scotland's players was focusing on keeping calm in difficult situations and displaying great maturity on the pitch.
They were supported by a strong team, with many players contributing to the effort.
The most notable changes made during this period include the addition of talented flanker Simon Webster to the squad after an injury to star forward Mauro Bergamasco.
Cristian Stoica took over center duties from veteran center David Dal Maso, who was ruled out for the rest of the tournament with a serious knee injury.

Scotland has made several key changes ahead of their match against Italy, and one of the most notable is the return of Simon Taylor to the team after recovering from a serious knee injury that plagued him throughout the tournament.

Injury updates:
- Captain C Paterson was ruled out with an arm injury
- R DE Marigny suffered a head injury in training
- S Wabuzi was diagnosed with a heart condition, but is expected to play
- J Dunbar has a concussion and will be sidelined for the rest of the tournament
- G Intoppa was benched after missing an opening chance
- D Dal Maso missed the game due to a knee injury
phi:2.7b: Italy's coach John Kirwan has emphasized the importance of avoiding mistakes and staying calm in order to avoid a third consecutive defeat at the Six Nations tournament.

They have made changes to their lineup, with Cristian Stoica returning as a center and David dal Maso joining the team at open-side after Mauro Bergamasco was ruled out for the rest of the competition.
Scotland coach Matt Williams is optimistic about Italy's chances despite previous defeats, believing they will be able to beat them.
Italy has made four changes to their lineup, including bringing back Simon Taylor who had been injured and making two new substitutions.
orca-mini:3b: On Saturday, Scotland will face Italy in the eighth edition of the Six Nations Championship.
The match will take place at Murrayfield in Edinburgh and will start at 1400 GMT on BBC1, Five Live and this website.
Scotland head coach Matt Williams is under pressure to win his first Six Nations victory after his team lost both their opening games at home against Ireland and Wales.
Italy have not won a game since last year's tournament and are traveling to Edinburgh with high hopes.
Despite a record of only two victories from 14 Tests, Williams is confident that his team can defeat the Azzurri.
The Scotland side has been bolstered by the return of Simon Taylor after a knee injury and two new players have been included in the starting line-up.
Italy coach John Kirwan has warned his side to avoid mistakes that saw them lose against Wales.
The match will be broadcasted on various platforms including BBC1, Five Live and this website.

granite3.1-dense:2b: On Saturday, 26 February at 1400 GMT, Italy faces off against Scotland at Murrayfield in Edinburgh for a Six Nations match.
This will be Scotland coach Matt Williams' first victory after eight attempts.
Last year, Italy's only win was against Scotland, ending their campaign without a victory.

Italy has lost both their home games, to Ireland and Wales, but arrives in Edinburgh with renewed hope under coach John Kirwan, who emphasizes the need for error-free play to avoid a third consecutive defeat.
Italy's lineup includes experienced players like Cristian Stoica at center and David dal Maso at open-side flanker due to Mauro Bergamasco's injury.
Scotland, on the other hand, has made two changes: Simon Webster replaces Simon Danielli on the wing and Simon Taylor returns after a year-long injury absence for Jason White.
Williams remains optimistic despite Scotland's poor record of two wins from 14 Tests, expressing confidence in his team's ability to secure a victory over Italy.
The match will feature players such as Finn Russell and Stuart Hogg for Scotland, and Cueto, Bassano, D'Apuzzo, and Parisse for Italy.
